questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented with symptoms of dragging discomfort in the left scrotum that worsens with prolonged standing. On palpation, the left scrotum feels like a bag of worms. What is the first-line intervention for this condition?

choices.text: Surgical ligation of the testicular veins

questions.solution:
The first line intervention for a symptomatic varicocele is percutaneous embolisation of gonadal veins.

That patient presents with classic symptoms of varicocele-dragging discomfort in the scrotum, which, on palpation, feels like a bag of worms. When the discomfort is significant, then percutaneous embolisation of the gonadal veins is the usual first-line intervention. If this is not possible, or if the varicocele recurs (as it does in around 20% after embolisation), then surgical ligation of the testicular veins (Option B) is the appropriate treatment, although recurrence can occur even after such surgery.

Percutaneous embolisation is typically done under local anaesthesia as an outpatient procedure. Through a tiny skin incision, a small catheter (tube) is inserted into the varicocele vein under X-ray guidance. A tiny quantity of contrast, or X-ray dye, is injected to verify the catheter's location. Subsequently, small balloons, platinum or stainless steel coils, or other materials are introduced into the vein. They are employed to obstruct it and terminate the varicocele's pressure or backflow. The catheter is taken out after establishing that there is no flow in the affected vein.

Other options:

Option A: Plication (Lord’s) is performed in a case of Hydrocele.

Option D: Aspiration and Excision are performed for Epididymal cyst and Spermatocele.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following renal injuries from least severe to most severe -
  1. Laceration of the pelvic ureteric junction 
  2. Subcapsular, non-expanding hematoma 
  3. Laceration up to renal medulla
  4. Injury confined to Gerota’s fascia
  5. Avulsion of renal hilum
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of renal injuries from least to most severe is 2-4-3-1-5.

  • Subcapsul, non-expanding hematoma (Least severe)
  • Injury confined to Gerota’s fascia
  • Laceration up to renal medulla
  • Laceration of the pelvic ureteric junction
  • Avulsion of the renal hilum (Most severe)

Renal injuries are mostly seen as a result of blunt trauma. Kidneys are the second most common visceral organ to be injured due to blunt trauma after the spleen. 

The examination includes findings related to the location of impact, flank ecchymosis, and gross or microscopic hematuria. Close attention to the entry and exit points in penetrating injuries is also important to estimate the trajectory of the missile. 

Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross haematuria, shock and microscopic haematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.

CECT is the investigation of choice. It assesses the extent of the injury, showing laceration, extravasation, surrounding haemorrhage, and vessel injury. It also shows non-renal injuries and effectively stages renal pedicle injuries. Arterial occlusion will manifest as rim enhancement of the normal renal contour. 

Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration.

Absolute indications for surgical intervention in renal trauma are:

  • Massive haemorrhage
  • Renal pedicle avulsion (grade 5 injury)
  • Expanding, pulsatile, or uncontained retroperitoneal hematoma

Relative indications are:

  • Large laceration of the renal pelvis or avulsion of the ureteropelvic junction
  • Bowel or pancreatic injuries
  • Persistent urinary leakage, postinjury urinoma, or perinephric abscess 
  • Complete renal artery thrombosis of both kidneys 
  • Renal hypertension
The five grade-classification of renal injuries by "The Organ Injury Scaling system of the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST)" is explained in the pearl given below.

questions.text: Which phase of damage control surgery focuses on the correction of coagulopathy?
questions.solution:
Phase 2 of damage control surgery focuses on the correction of coagulopathy, hypothermia and acidosis.

Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centres on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries. 

It includes an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and closure of the abdomen in an eﬀort to blunt the physiologic response to prolonged shock and massive haemorrhage.

Phases of damage control surgery are: 

  • Phase I (initial exploration) - this phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active hemorrhage and contamination
  • Phase II (secondary resuscitation) - this phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy and acidosis
  • Phase III (definitive operation) - this phase consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. It typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the triangle of pain?

choices.text: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.solution:
The ilioinguinal nerve is not a content of the triangle of pain.

The triangle of pain (Electrical hazard zone) is an anatomical landmark encountered during laparoscopic hernia repair surgery. Any damage to the contents of this structure can lead to chronic pain following hernia repair.

It is bounded by:

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

The ilioinguinal nerve is a branch of the L1 nerve root. It enters the abdominal wall by piercing the transversus abdominis muscle on the posterior aspect. It enters the inguinal canal as it goes inferomedially. It supplies the anterior surface of the scrotum or labia majora. It can be injured during open hernia repair.

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady presents with diarrhea and malabsorption after undergoing massive intestinal resection for small bowel infarction. What would be the mainstay of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario (diarrhea, malabsorption, and a history of massive intestinal resection) is suggestive of short bowel syndrome (<150 cm of the residual small bowel). Home parenteral nutrition (HPN) is the mainstay of treatment for short bowel syndrome. 

Although the other drugs mentioned have a role in the management, they are not the mainstay of management.

The causes of short bowel syndrome include:

  • In adults- 
    • Acute mesenteric ischemia - most common cause in adults
    • Crohn’s disease 
    • Trauma
  • In children- Bowel atresia and midgut volvulus

Clinical features of short bowel syndrome are as follows:

  • Diarrhea (due to hypergastrinemia and gastric hypersecretion, or unabsorbed bile salts in the colon)
  • Steatorrhea (due to the depletion of the bile salt pool)
  • Gallstones (due to interruption of the enterohepatic cycle of bile salts)
  • Renal stones (due to increased absorption of oxalate in the colon) 
  • Peptic ulcer (due to hypergastrinemia and gastric hypersecretion)
  • Fat-soluble (vitamin A, D, E, and K) and B12 vitamin deficiencies

Because the capacity for bile salt and vitamin B12 absorption is unique to the terminal ileum, proximal midgut resection is better tolerated than distal. An intact ileocecal valve is associated with slower intestinal transit and lesser malabsorption.

The management of short bowel syndrome is as follows:

The mainstay of treatment for short bowel syndrome remains home parenteral nutrition (HPN). With its development, the majority of people with short bowel syndrome are able to live a relatively normal life with long-term survival.

Medical therapy-

  • Fluid and electrolyte replacement, as well as Total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Enteral nutrition is gradually introduced, after recovery from the acute phase.
  • Parenteral vitamin B12
  • Fat-soluble vitamins, as well as calcium, magnesium, and zinc supplementation
  • Proton pump blockers to increases gastric pH
  • Oral cholestyramine to bind with bile salts 
  • Antimotility drugs such as loperamide hydrochloride or diphenoxylate to delay small-intestinal transit. 
  • Octreotide to reduce the volume of gastrointestinal secretions 
  • Hormonal therapy to promote intestinal adaptation, such as glutamine, growth hormone, and GLP-2 analogue (teduglutide)

Surgery- 

  • Longitudinal intestinal lengthening and tailoring (LILT)/Bianchi procedure 
  • Serial transverse enteroplasty procedure (STEP) procedure

Intestinal transplant is indicated only in life-threatening complications from intestinal failure or long-term Total parenteral nutrition (TPN). It can be done as an isolated procedure, combined intestine/liver transplantation, or rarely as multi-visceral transplantation. Isolated small bowel graft is the most commonly used intestinal graft.

Intestinal transplant is associated with vigorous graft rejection reactions and Graft vs Host Disease (GVHD) due to the gut-associated lymphoid tissue. The most dangerous complication is sepsis from increased intestinal permeability allowing bacterial translocation.

questions.text: A patient presented with a head injury followed by a brief loss of consciousness. His GCS score is 15. As per the NICE guidelines, all of the following are indications for a CT scan within 1 hour, except:

choices.text: More than one episode of vomiting

questions.solution:
As per the NICE guidelines, a clotting disorder is an indication for a CT scan within 8 hours (not within 1 hour) in a patient with a head injury with some loss of consciousness/amnesia.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with a history of serous discharge from an external opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. Where is the location of the internal opening likely to be?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a fistula-in-ano. Here, the external opening was at 8'O clock which is considered posterior. According to the Goodsall rule, fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline (6’O clock position). Hence, the fistulous tract opens internally at 6’O clock position.

Goodsall’s rule:

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the internal posterior midline.

Exceptions to Goodsall’s Rule

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Investigations:

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

  • Control of constipation
  • Sitz bath
  • Fistulotomy
  • Fistulectomy
  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
  • Setons
  • Advancement flaps

questions.text: A patient presents with a hernia lateral to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a hernia lateral to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of an indirect hernia. A Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for its management.

The contents of an indirect hernia protrude laterally to the inferior epigastric artery. The sac of an indirect inguinal hernia passes from the internal inguinal ring obliquely towards the external inguinal ring and then reaches the scrotum. Whereas, the contents of a direct hernia protrude outward, forward, and medially to the inferior epigastric artery and the internal inguinal ring.

A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to fit the canal to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other surgical methods used to repair a hernia are:

Bassini repair is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendons to the inguinal ligament. 

Shouldice repair is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate.

Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia

McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femoral hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's ligament.

Stoppa-Rives repair is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitoneal space.

Herniotomy is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done

questions.text:
You are a newly posted intern in the department of surgery. During your routine ward rounds, you notice a patient with an ulcer being treated with the following therapy. Which of the following statements are true regarding this modality of treatment?
  1. The therapy involves the application of continuous pressure of -250 mm of Hg
  2. It increases blood flow and decreases wound edema
  3. It creates a suitable bed for a flap or graft cover
  4. It consists of an airtight and sealed wound drain covered with an opaque adhesive film
  5. Everyday redressing of the wound is not required with this therapy
questions.solution:
The image above shows the vacuum-assisted closure of an ulcer. The true statements regarding VAC are 2, 3, and 5.

VAC therapy is also called negative pressure wound closure. It creates an intermittent (not continuous) negative pressure of -125 mm Hg to promote the formation of healthy granulation tissue.

It is made up of foam with a perforated wound drain covered and plastered with transparent plastic/ adhesive film. It is commonly used in the management of pressure bed sores and diabetic ulcers. It creates a suitable niche and bed for harvesting flaps. Everyday redressing of the wound is not required with this therapy. 

It acts by:

  • Reducing tissue edema
  • Clearing interstitial fluid
  • Improves perfusion and increases the healing process

questions.text: A 39-year-old man, who is a chronic alcoholic, presented with complaints of abdominal distension, yellowish discoloration of eyes, and dark-colored urine for the past 6 months.  After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe and is scheduled for left hemi-hepatectomy. Which of the following segments has to be removed in the patient?

choices.text: II, III, IV, V, and VI

questions.solution:
In left hemi-hepatectomy (also called left hepatectomy), the segments marked as II, III, and IV should be removed. 

Cantlie’s line or main portal fissure extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein. The liver has 3 major fissures and 3 minor fissures.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage. Segment I corresponds to the liver's caudate lobe, and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver. 

The Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Segments removed in various liver surgeries:

  • Right hepatectomy or right hemi-hepatectomy - V, VI, VII, VIII
  • Right tri-sectionectomy or extended right hepatectomy - IV, V, VI, VII, VIII
  • Left hepatectomy or left hemi-hepatectomy - II, III, and IV
  • Left tri-sectionectomy or extended left hepatectomy - II, III, IV, V, and VIII
  • Left lateral sectionectomy or bi-segmentectomy - II and III
  • Right posterior sectionectomy - VI, VII
  • Caudate lobectomy or segmentectomy - I

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

questions.text: A patient had a painless episode of profuse per rectal bleeding. After initial stabilization, a colonoscopy was performed and the below finding was noted. Later on, this patient was diagnosed with Heyde's syndrome. Which cardiac valvular abnormality would be most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given endoscopic image is suggestive of angiodysplasia seen in Heyde's syndrome. The cardiac valvular abnormality most likely to be seen in this condition is aortic stenosis.

Heyde’s syndrome is a rare multisystem disorder characterized by the clinical triad of:

  • Aortic stenosis 
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding from angiodysplasia
  • Acquired type 2 vWD (secondary to valvular stenosis, returns to normal once the valve is replaced)

Angiodysplasia is a vascular malformation that commonly causes hemorrhage from the colon in patients over the age of 60 years. The cecum is the most common site of angiodysplasia followed by the colon. In the colon angiodysplasia can occur anywhere, however, it is more commonly found in the right colon than the transverse and the left colon. The malformations consist of dilated tortuous submucosal veins.

Investigations include colonoscopy which identifies small reddish, raised areas sizing a few millimetres. Selective superior and inferior mesenteric angiography shows the site and extent of the lesion by a 'blush' of contrast.

Treatment options rest on the principles of stabilizing the patient and localizing the bleeding with colonoscopy and argon laser. In severe uncontrolled bleeding, surgery is necessary.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with a scrotal swelling. On examination, one can feel the testis separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling shows a brilliant transillumination. A crystal clear fluid is noticed with aspiration. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an Epididymal cyst. The swelling is palpable separately from the testis. This rules out primary hydrocoele as swelling cannot be palpated separately from the testis. Aspiration of crystal clear fluid rules out spermatocele as it contains barley-colored fluid due to the presence of spermatozoa.

Epididymal cyst occurs due to cystic degeneration of epididymis. They usually occur in middle age and are bilateral. The tense cysts are usually posterior to the testes and feel like clusters of tiny grapes. It is visible on USG as anechoic cysts different from the testes. Treatment involves the excision of the cyst if it is single. Partial or total resection of the epididymis is required in multilocular cysts.

Other options:

Option C: Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis in the scrotum. It will be brilliantly transilluminating and testes will not be separately palpable. USG will show anechoic (due to fluid) reflection. Treatment involves Jaboulay's operation, in which the eversion of the sac upon itself is done to prevent refilling of the hydrocoele sac.

Option D: Varicocele is an abnormal dilatation and enlargement of the scrotal venous plexus draining the testis. They are more common on the left side. They are usually asymptomatic. First-line treatment is embolization in symptomatic cases. Palomo operation can be done which is the ligation of the testicular vein in the retroperitoneum.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is incorrect about retractile testes?
  1. The scrotum with retractile testis is abnormal
  2. They are more common than true undescended testes
  3. Ectopic testes is a differential of retractile testes
  4. Chair test helps to differentiate retractile testis from ectopic testis
  5. Retractile testes may require orchidopexy
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 5 are incorrect, as retractile testes require no treatment, and the scrotum is generally normal. 

A retractile testis is a normally developed and descended testis that retracts back into the inguinal canal due to hyper reflexive cremasteric muscle contraction. It is present in the scrotum and occasionally jumps to lie in the inguinal canal. They are more common than true undescended testes. The scrotum of a boy with such a retractile testis is normal.

Therefore, any stimulation of the skin of the scrotum or thigh causes the testis to ascend and temporarily disappear into the inguinal canal. When the cremaster relaxes, the testis reappears in the scrotum.

The scrotum of a boy with such a retractile testis is normal (normal rugosity is seen).

Retractile testes require no treatment. 

Note: The chair test helps to differentiate retractile testis from ectopic testis because both of them describe a condition wherein the testis lies in an abnormal position. 

Chair Test:  Here, The young patient is asked to sit on a chair, hugging his knees to his chest. This maneuver helps the retractile testis to get pushed down back to the bottom of the scrotum. By this test, the retractile testis can be differentiated from the ectopic testis.

Remember:

Ectopic testis must be differentiated from retractile testis, both of which describe conditions wherein the testis lies in an abnormal position. 

The ectopic testis is present outside the usual path of descent from the abdomen to the scrotum. Some of the ectopic sites include the femoral triangle, the root of the penis, and the perineum. However, a retractile testis is present in the scrotum and occasionally jumps to lie in the inguinal canal. 

An ectopic testis is usually treated with orchidopexy.

A neonate was brought by his mother with complaints of non-passage of stools and abdominal distension. After a detailed examination, he was suspected to have an inherited autosomal recessive disorder resulting from a CFTR gene mutation. In the Bishop-Koop procedure, the proximal distended limb is joined to the side of the distal small bowel. This is vented by a chimney to the abdominal wall. The Bishop-Koop operation with its irrigating stoma is now only rarely used.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease was diagnosed with high-grade dysplasia after upper GI endoscopy and biopsy. What will be your next step in management according to the Seattle protocol?
questions.solution:
According to the Seattle protocol, in a patient with high-grade dysplasia, radiofrequency ablation/argon photocoagulation/endoscopic mucosal resection is performed first, and then, the patient is followed up after 3 months.

Barrett's esophagus is a metaplastic change (squamous to columnar epithelium change) in the lower end of the esophagus as a result of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease. It increases the risk of developing esophageal adenocarcinoma. 

 Barrett’s esophagus can be

  • Classical Barrett's esophagus - >3 cm of columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus.
  • Short segment  Barrett's esophagus - <3 cm of columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus.
  • Cardia metaplasia - microscopic Barrett’s in the GE junction. In cardia metaplasia, due to a lack of macroscopic changes, an endoscopic biopsy is difficult. So, chromoendoscopy is the ideal investigation. Here, mucosa is first stained by methylene blue to highlight abnormal mucosa.

On endoscopy, Barrett's is recognized as areas of red, velvety mucosa extending proximally from the gastroesophageal junction. Such areas alternate with normal pale squamous esophageal mucosa. Diagnostic confirmation is by endoscopic biopsy. Biopsy reveals intestinal metaplasia characterized by the presence of goblet cells. Goblet cells are seen as cells with pale mucous vacuoles that stain blue.

The Seattle protocol is ideally followed to detect early dysplastic changes in Barrett's esophagus. Here, a 4 quadrant biopsy specimen is taken 1-2 cm apart throughout the area of intestinal metaplasia.

  • No signs of dysplasia - continue 2 yearly surveillance. 
  • Low-grade dysplasia - APC or RFA or EMR followed by 6 monthly surveillance
  • High-grade dysplasia - APC or RFA or EMR followed by 3 monthly surveillance

APC - Argon photocoagulation

RFA - Radiofrequency ablation

EMR - Endoscopic mucosal resection

Lugol’s iodine is used for squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The image is that of a Hasson trocar which is used in the open method of creating pneumoperitoneum.

There are two methods used for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum:

  1. Closed method
  2. Open method

The open method is preferred for patients who have undergone previous abdominal surgeries as the small bowel may be adherent to the undersurface of the abdominal wound. The use of the open technique for creating a pneumoperitoneum avoids the morbidity related to a blind puncture.

To achieve this, a 1 cm vertical or transverse incision is made at the level of the umbilicus, stay sutures are applied, and the fascia is dissected. Free penetration into the abdominal cavity is confirmed by the gentle introduction of a finger. A Hasson trocar (shown below) is inserted and anchored, and a pneumoperitoneum is created. This is the Hasson or modified Hasson approach. 

The closed method using the Veress needle has a small but significant potential for intestinal or vascular injury on the introduction of the needle or trocar. Proper placement of the needle can be determined by the inability to re-aspirate injected saline. The normal insufflation rate is 4-6 litres/min.

The image below shows a Veress needle.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a history of gonorrhea now presents with hesitancy, straining, and a poor stream of urine. Which of the following structures is most commonly affected in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-inflammatory urethral stricture. The structure marked 3 in the image is the bulbar urethra which is most commonly affected.

The infection in the periurethral glands persists after inadequately treated gonorrhea. The infection spreads to cause periurethritis, which heals by fibrosis. They are more common within 1 year of infection.

Causes of urethral stricture include:

  • Trauma (most common)                                    
    • Bulbar urethral injury
    • Pelvic fracture 
  • Infection
    • Secondary to urethritis
    • Secondary to balanitis
  • Iatrogenic
    • Secondary to urethral catheterization

Clinical features include hesitancy, poor stream, and straining. Other complaints like postmicturition dribbling, incomplete bladder emptying, and retention can also occur. 

Uroflowmetry, urethroscopy, urethrography, and ultrasound can be done.

Urinary tract infection is the most common complication of urethral stricture.

Management options include:

  • Urethral dilatation in elderly men with short strictures
  • Urethroplasty in case of trauma
  • Urethrotomy

The below image shows the parts of the urethra.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with chest pain and difficulty in swallowing for the past 8 months. A High-resolution manometry revealed massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal esophagus and absent peristalsis. What is the best management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture points towards achalasia cardia, for which the treatment of choice is laparoscopic Heller's myotomy + Dor fundoplication.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. This is due to the loss of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach’s) plexus. Based on the manometric findings it can be classified into 3 types.

Diagnosis is established by high-resolution oesophageal manometry which shows

  • Absent peristalsis.
  • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation.
  • Raised esophageal resting pressure.
  • LOS pressure may be elevated, but is often normal.

Treatment of achalasia cardia:

Non-surgical:

  • Medical management with sublingual nitroglycerin, nitrates, and calcium-channel blockers for symptomatic relief.
  • Pneumatic dilatation
  • Botox injection

Surgical—Treatment of choice

  • Laparoscopic Heller's myotomy is the definitive management - The major complication associated with this procedure is gastro-oesophageal reflux. So it is best to combine it with partial anterior fundoplication (Heller–Dor operation).
  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is a recently introduced, advanced natural-orifice approach for myotomy.
  • Open Esophageal Myotomy - rarely done. 

Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM).

 

Option A: Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy is used to treat infantile pyloric stenosis.

Option B: Dohlman's procedure is the treatment of choice in Zenker's diverticulum.

Option C: Nissen's fundoplication is total fundoplication done in GERD

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt abdominal trauma. He is found to have a splenic injury with a ruptured subcapsular hematoma and is hemodynamically unstable. What is the grade of injury and the best course of management?
questions.solution:
A ruptured subcapsular hematoma is suggestive of grade III splenic injury and the best course of management in a hemodynamically unstable patient is splenectomy.

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area) or laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (10-50% of surface area) or laceration, 1-3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Hematoma > 50% of surface area or expanding

  • Ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding Or
    Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving
    trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
or
A hilar vascular injury that devascularizes the spleen.

Management of splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively. Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals, hematocrit, and serial CECT. If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis. If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable, then a splenorrhaphy is done. 

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and melena. UGI endoscopy reveals a smooth, round tumor with central ulceration in the stomach. Microscopy is as below. Which of the following is correct regarding this tumor?

choices.text: Wedge resection with lymphadenectomy is primary treatment

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, endoscopic findings, and the histological image showing spindle-shaped tumor cells are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). It is a radioresistant tumor and does not respond to conventional chemotherapy. 

GIST are the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, the stomach being the most common site. They arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal, the pacemaker cells of the GIT. GIST is seen in the 5th to 6th decade of life and has an equal preponderance among males and females. Most patients present with haematemesis, melena, or vague abdominal pain. The most common indications for surgery include bleeding and obstruction.

The GIST may occur in a sporadic form or as part of familial syndromes. In sporadic GIST, the most common mutations seen are gain-of-function mutation in KIT (75-80%) and PDGFRA mutation (8%). Microscopically, GIST has elongated spindle cells or plumper epithelioid cells, or a mixed pattern.

The below image shows the microscopy of GIST composed of bundles, or fascicles, of spindle-shaped tumor cells.

Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient GIST is a subset of wild-type GIST seen with Carney triad or Carney-Stratakis syndrome. It is c-KIT & PDGFRA negative. 

The management of GIST is as follows,

Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST) Treatment of choice
Low risk of malignancy Complete surgical resection + Surveillance
Intermediate to high risk of malignancy Complete surgical resection + adjuvant Imatinib for 3 years
Unresectable Neoadjuvant Imatinib
Metastatic Imatinib

Imatinib can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA. Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) - deficient GIST is imatinib-resistant, so sunitinib, sorafenib, or regorafenib can be used instead.

During surgical resection of GIST, care must be taken to prevent capsule rupture, which causes seeding of nearby tissues leading to relapse in 100% of the cases. If capsule rupture occurs, adjuvant therapy with imatinib is indicated regardless of tumor extent.

Other options:

Option A: GIST does not respond to conventional chemotherapy. They respond to targeted chemotherapy (tyrosine kinase inhibitors) such as imatinib.

Option C: Lymphadenectomy is not done in GIST as it usually does not show lymph node metastasis.

Option D: Gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GIST), which are succinate dehydrogenase deficient (SDH) do not respond to treatment with imatinib.

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

Related Pearl: Carney's complex, triad, and diad

Carney complex includes:

  • Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast
  • Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi
  • Endocrine overactivity - primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly

 Carney's triad includes:

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extraadrenal paraganglioma

Carney-Stratakis syndrome also called Carney's diad includes:

  • GIST
  • Paraganglioma

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of testicular tumors?

choices.text: Radical inguinal orchiectomy is the gold standard treatment for excision of the primary tumor
Chest and abdominal axial imaging are  not the main staging tools
Recurrence usually occurs within the first 2 years and in the retroperitoneum

questions.solution:
Option B is the false statement as chest and abdominal axial imaging are the main staging tools in the management of testicular tumors.

Testicular cancer is the most common cancer in men aged 20 to 40 years and the second most common cancer in young men aged 15 to 19 years. 95% of testicular tumors are germ cell tumors; the rest originate from stromal cells (Leydig or Sertoli cells). Germ cell tumors can be classified as either seminomatous or nonseminomatous. Seminoma constitutes more than 50% of all testicular cancers. 

Most patients present with testicular pain or a testicular mass. Respiratory symptoms, back pain, weight loss, or gynecomastia may indicate metastatic disease (10–20%). A testicular mass is considered malignant till proven otherwise. Similarly, retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy in young men should be considered metastatic testicular cancer. 

The gold standard for the excision of a primary testicular tumor is a radical inguinal orchiectomy (Option A). A partial orchiectomy via an inguinal route may be considered in certain circumstances, such as lymphomas. Chest and abdominal axial imaging are the main staging tools for testicular tumors. The spread of testicular cancer follows an extremely predictable pattern. The interaortocaval lymph node is typically the first site of metastasis for right testicular cancer, followed by the paracaval and paraaortic lymph nodes. Left-sided testicular cancer rarely crosses to the paracaval lymph nodes. Tumor markers, distant metastases, and local stages are all included in clinical TNM staging.

Percutaneous testicular biopsy(Option 3) is contraindicated due to the risk of seeding in the scrotal wall. An open testicular biopsy by delivery of the testicle through the inguinal canal is recommended in cases where metastatic disease to the testicle is suspected. Recurrence usually occurs within the first two years and in the retroperitoneum(Option 4).

2. Arrange the following options in the correct order of operational steps in the Truncal vagotomy procedure.

 a. Division of the anterior vagus
 b. Division of the posterior vagus
 c. Mobilization of the esophagus
questions.solution:
The correct order of operational steps in Truncal vagotomy is a-c-b.

Division of the anterior vagus — Mobilization of the esophagus — Division of the posterior vagus

Truncal vagotomy, combined with drainage, was the mainstay of treatment of duodenal ulceration for many years. Cutting off the section of the vagus nerve that is critically involved in the secretion of gastric acid reduces the maximal acid output by approximately 50%. 

Other surgeries for duodenal ulcers include:

Gastrectomy-
Billroth I gastrectomy- The lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum. 
Billroth II gastrectomy- Two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed, and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum.

Gastrojejunostomy- Because of the potential for mortality after gastrectomy, the use of gastrojejunostomy alone in treating duodenal ulceration was developed. Reflux of alkali from the small bowel into the stomach reduced duodenal acid exposure and was often successful in healing the ulcer. However, because the jejunal loop was exposed directly to gastric acid, stomal ulceration was extremely common hence, the procedure in isolation was ineffective.

Gastroenterostomy- The jejunum is anastomosed to the posterior, dependent stomach wall.

Highly selective vagotomy- The anterior and posterior vagus nerves are preserved, but all branches to the fundus and body of the stomach are divided.

Truncal vagotomy and antrectomy- In addition to a truncal vagotomy, the stomach antrum is removed, thus removing the source of gastrin, and the gastric remnant is joined to the duodenum. The recurrence rates after this procedure are exceedingly low. 

Related Pearl: Types Of Gastric Ulcers

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is considered immediately life threatening in patients with penetrating chest trauma?
questions.solution:
In patients with penetrating chest trauma, pericardial tamponade is an immediately life-threatening condition. Other conditions mentioned are considered potentially life-threatening.

Life-threatening injuries can be remembered as the deadly dozen. Six are immediately life-threatening and should be sought for and managed during the primary survey, and six are potentially life-threatening and should be detected during the secondary survey.        

Immediately life-threatening:

  • Airway obstruction 
  • Tension pneumothorax 
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Open pneumothorax 
  • Massive haemothorax 
  • Flail chest

Potentially life-threatening:

  • Aortic injuries 
  • Tracheobronchial injuries
  • Myocardial contusion 
  • Rupture of diaphragm 
  • Esophageal injuries 
  • Pulmonary contusion

questions.text: All of the following are premalignant lesions of invasive penile carcinoma except
questions.solution:
Of the listed conditions, Bowenoid papulosis is not a premalignant lesion.

Bowenoid papulosis occurs in young, sexually active adults. It presents as multiple reddish-brown papular lesions. It is histologically indistinguishable from Bowen disease. However, it never develops into invasive carcinoma and usually regresses spontaneously. 

Other options:

Option A: Bowen disease is a type of penile intraepithelial neoplasia that occurs on the shaft of the penis. It presents as a grey-white, opaque plaque and is associated with HPV 16. It transforms into infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma in approximately 10% of patients.

Option B: Leukoplakia of glans is another type of premalignant lesion for invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the penis. It is similar to leukoplakia of the oral cavity. It is histologically characterized by hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis, with associated low-grade dysplasia. 

Option C: Erythroplasia of Queyrat is another type of penile intraepithelial neoplasia similar to Bowen disease. It presents as a red cutaneous patch on the glans penis.

questions.text: A young patient has been brought from a road traffic accident with a pelvic fracture. On examination, there is marked bruising of the pubic area, scrotum and penis. Urinary retention, blood at the urethral meatus, and a high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination are also noted. How do you confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario of a young patient with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination and a history of a road traffic accident, the most likely diagnosis is membranous urethral injury. The diagnosis is confirmed by performing a retrograde urethrogram.

A retrograde urethrogram with water-soluble contrast is used for confirmation of the diagnosis. The following image shows an image of retrograde urethrogram contrast leakage at the membranous urethra.

Urethral injuries in men usually occur after catheterisation or during cystoscopy. Injuries following external trauma are rare but mainly affect the bulbar or the membranous urethra. 

Membranous urethral rupture usually occurs following a road traffic accident, crush injury, or a fall. It is associated with pelvic fracture and extraperitoneal bladder rupture. Clinical features include urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and a high-riding prostate on digital examination. Bruising is seen over the pubic area, scrotum, and penis.

Management is by inserting a suprapubic catheter. If there is an associated bladder rupture, the bladder will not be seen on the ultrasound, and management in such a case is by exploration, repair, and placement of a suprapubic catheter.

Other Options:

Option A: Intravenous urography is used in the investigation of patients with suspected urinary tract calculi. This has been superseded by non-contrast CT. 

Option B: Cystourethroscopy, also known as a cystoscopy, is a procedure that helps us directly visualise the bladder, urethra, prostate, urethral sphincter, and ureteral orifices.

Option C: A voiding cystogram is used in the diagnosis of posterior urethral valves. It would show a dilated bladder with a dilated prostatic urethra above an obstruction at the level of the posterior urethral valve.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has been in the ICU for the past 1 month due to end-stage liver failure. He is not eligible for a transplant and his doctors have said there is nothing they can do at this stage. His family has consented to organ donation once his heart stops. Which of the categories of non-beating heart donors would this patient fall into as per the modified Maastricht classification?
questions.solution:
The patient would fall under category III. 

Modified Maastricht classification- Categories of non-heart-beating donors:

  • Uncontrolled - transplant team not present or prepared
    • Category I - includes victims of accident and suicide who are found dead at the scene and resuscitation is deemed pointless (e.g. fatal cervical spine fracture).
    • Category II - donors are mostly victims of sudden cardiac or cerebral catastrophes who are brought to emergency departments while being resuscitated by ambulance personnel or who die in the department. Other sources include patients suffering an isolated brain injury, anoxia, and stroke, and victims of major trauma who died soon after hospital admission.
    • Category V - Unexpected cardiac arrest during intensive care.
  • Controlled - transplant team present and prepared
    • Category III - encompasses patients who are dying, often in an intensive care unit. These are the patients awaiting cardiac arrest where the treating clinicians have decided to withdraw treatment and not commence resuscitation for various reasons.
    • Category IV - comprises patients who suffer unexpected cardiac arrest during or after the determination of brain death.

Lifestyle modification and medications are the first-line treatment for GERD. Surgical management is done for patients who have persistent symptoms or develop complications despite appropriate medical therapy. Fundoplication is the procedure in which the fundus of the stomach is wrapped around the lower end of the esophagus and is done for GERD.

questions.text: An IV urogram of a child who presented with recurrent urinary tract infection is shown below. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the likely diagnosis.

choices.text: The upper pole ureter inserts superolaterally in the bladder
The lower pole ureter may lead to vesicoureteral reflux
The upper pole ureter is usually obstructed
The lower pole ureter inserts into the bladder through a shorter submucosal tunnel

questions.solution:
The given scenario with the image of the intravenous urogram showing the "drooping lily" sign is suggestive of a completely duplicated collecting system. According to Weigert Meyer's rule of complete duplication of the ureter, the ureter draining from the upper pole of the kidney enters the bladder medial and inferior to the ureter draining from the lower pole.

This is a common congenital anomaly of the urinary tract which occurs due to the division of the ureter as it ascends upwards from the bladder to the renal parenchyma during the embryological period of life. Thus, the person might have two collecting systems for one kidney.

There are 2 types of duplication:

  1. Incomplete- Y ureter arises when the ureteric bud bifurcates after its initial development from the mesonephric duct
  2. Complete- 2 separate ureteric buds. One is at normal while the second one is at a lower position. The lower pole ureter is associated with vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) due to its insertion into the bladder through a short submucosal tunnel. The upper pole ureter commonly gets in obstructed resulting in scarring.

Often, the ureter that supplies the upper half of the kidney becomes obstructed. If the upper pole collecting system of the kidney is completely obstructed, only the normally draining lower pole collecting system is visualized on the intravenous urogram and it looks like a drooping lily. 

The condition is asymptomatic in adults while children have VUR. Females are more commonly affected. Voiding is normal but prolonged dribbling of urine is seen.

According to Weigart Meyer's rule of congenital complete duplication of the ureter:

  • The ureter draining the upper segment of the kidney inserts in the bladder inferior and medial to the ureter draining the lower segment of the kidney (Weigert–Meyer rule). The lower moiety of the completely duplicated system is generally normal. 
  • In case of an incomplete duplication, there is only one ureteric orifice on that side of the bladder.

Ureteropelvic junction obstruction in a patient with duplicated collecting system can be managed with laparoscopic procedures such as pyeloplasty. Other options include a partial or complete nephrectomy.

questions.text: A 40 year old male comes to OPD with a chronic history of  deformity of penis, erectile dysfunction and pain on erection. On examination there were palpable penile plaques. What is the surgical procedure commonly employed to correct this penile deformity?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The most common surgical procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is the Nesbitt procedure. This corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture.

Options A and B: Lord’s operation and Jaboulay’s procedure are surgery performed for hydrocoele.

A chronic alcoholic patient presented with hematemesis. After the failure of all the treatment options, he underwent the following procedure for the management of portal hypertension. The surgeon decided to perform this procedure as it minimizes the risk of hepatic encephalopathy. Identify the shunt depicted in the image below.

[IVC-Inferior vena cava, PV-Portal vein, SV-Splenic vein, LRV-Left renal vein]
questions.solution:
The image shows Warre shunt (distal lienorenal shunt). This is the only selective shunt out of the four options given hence it has the least risk of hepatic encephalopathy. 

TIPS(Transjugular Intravenous Porto Systemic Shunt):

The main indication of TIPS is variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment and intractable ascites.

The shunts are inserted under local anesthesia, analgesia, and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. A guidewire is inserted via the internal jugular vein and superior vena cava into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

The major complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPS is portal vein occlusion.

Portal hypertension is defined by a portal pressure >5 mmHg.

Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is a treatment option whereby a percutaneous connection is created within the liver, between the portal and systemic circulations, to reduce portal pressure in patients with complications related to portal hypertension.

Complications of TIPS procedure:

  • Intraoperative complications- capsular hemorrhage
  • Early complication- hepatic encephalopathy
  • Late complication- recurrent variceal bleed
  • Delayed complication- total shunt occlusion

Shunts for portal hypertension:

  • Non-selective shunt- bowel and splenic blood is shunted
    • Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)
    • ECK fistula (portocaval shunt)
    • Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)
  • Selective shunt- only splenic blood is shunted
    • Warren shunt (distal lienorenal shunt)
    • Inokuchi shunt

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was diagnosed to be a case of colorectal cancer. On further evaluation, he was found to have desmoid tumours, epidermoid cysts and osteoma of the mandible. Genetic studies revealed APC gene mutation. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and APC gene mutation are suggestive of Gardner's syndrome(a variant of Familial adenomatous polyposis).

Gardner's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) caused by an abnormal APC gene on Chromosome 5. 

Components

  • Colorectal polyps
  • Osteomas of the jaw or skull
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Soft tissue tumours like desmoid tumours

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is defined clinically by the presence of more than 100 colorectal adenomas but is also characterised by duodenal adenomas and multiple extraintestinal manifestations. The lifetime risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%. 

The aim of surgery in FAP is to prevent the development of colorectal cancer. The surgical options are:

  1. Colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA);

  2. Restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (RPC);

  3. Total proctectomy and end ileostomy.

The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA).

Other Options:

Option A: If a brain tumor arises in a patient with either HNPCC or FAP, then the patient is considered to have Turcot syndrome.

Option B: Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)/ Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in one of the DNA mismatch repair genes. The most commonly affected genes are MLH1 and MSH2. It is characterised by an increased risk of colorectal cancer and also cancers of the endometrium, ovary, stomach and small intestine. 

Option D: Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by hyperpigmentation of the mouth and lips, and multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small and large intestines.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions can be detected routinely by using eFAST?
  1. Simple pneumothorax
  2. Cardiac tamponade
  3. Subcutaneous emphysema
  4. Renal injuries
  5. Free fluid in the abdomen
questions.solution:
Simple pneumothorax, cardiac tamponade, and free fluid in the abdomen can be detected early by using eFAST.

FAST is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. eFAST stands for extended FAST and incorporates Left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.

It is a quick, consistent, easily transportable, and non-intrusive test that can be conducted alongside resuscitation. eFAST demonstrates high precision at detecting >100 mL of free blood.

Limitations of eFAST are:

  1. Operator-dependent
  2. Bowel gas and subcutaneous air distort images.
  3. Can miss diaphragm, bowel, and pancreatic injuries
  4. Is unreliable for assessment of the retroperitoneum
  5. Cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma
  6. May need repeating or supplementing with other investigations

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used for considering liver transplantation in patients with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The Milan criteria are used to assess the suitability of patients with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma for liver transplantation. In order to be suitable for liver transplantation, the patient should have

  • a single tumor with a diameter of ≤5 cm
  • up to 3 tumors, each with a diameter ≤3 cm
  • no extra-hepatic involvement
  • no macrovascular invasion

Other options:

Option A: The Miami criteria were developed to ensure the adequacy of resection in parathyroid surgery. It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes.

Option B: King’s College selection criteria is used for liver transplantation in acute liver failure (paracetamol (acetaminophen) and non-paracetamol induced)

Option D: NEXUS criteria: There are five criteria included under NEXUS. If a trauma patient meets all five criteria, then no radiography is required and the cervical c-spine collar may be removed. However, if any one of the criteria is met then radiography is done to evaluate further.

questions.text: A surgeon performing an esophagectomy makes three incisions in three different places on the thorax, abdomen and neck. What is the name of this three-phase esophagectomy?
questions.solution:
This three-phase/three-incision esophagectomy is called the McKeown approach.

Three incisions are made in the neck, thorax, and abdomen during the three-incision esophagectomy, also known as the McKeown technique. An abdominal incision, a right thoracotomy, and a left neck incision are used to remove the esophageal tumour. The neck is where the esophagogastric anastomosis is situated.

Other options:

Option 2: During an Ivor Lewis esophagectomy, a right thoracotomy and an abdominal incision are used to remove the esophageal tumour. The upper chest is where the esophagogastric anastomosis is situated.

Option 3: Small incisions in the right chest (thoracoscopy) and abdomen are used to remove the esophageal tumour during a minimally invasive esophagectomy. The upper chest is where the esophagogastric anastomosis is situated.

Option 4: The transhiatal esophagectomy involves making a left neck incision and an abdominal incision to remove the esophageal tumour without the need for a thoracotomy. The neck is where the esophagogastric anastomosis is situated

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a choledochocele. As per Todani's classification, this would be classified under which of the following types of choledochal cysts?
questions.solution:
Choledochocele is classified as type III choledochal cyst as per Todani's classification. Type III cysts have dilation confined to the distal intrapancreatic portion of the common bile duct (CBD).

Choledochal cysts are cystic dilations of the common bile duct (CBD). They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass and abdominal pain.

There are mainly five types of choledochal cysts as follows:

  • Type I- is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II- it is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD, and joined to the CBD by a narrow stalk.
  • Type III- they have dilation confined to the distal intrapancreatic portion of the CBD and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA- the cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB- these choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease)- it consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

For which of the following can the instrument that is shown in the image be used?
  1. To hold fascia and galea aponeurotica in craniotomy
  2. To clamp the arterial wall of larger arteries during dissection
  3. To hold the vaginal wall during hysterectomy

The given image is of Allis' tissue forceps. It is used to hold skin flaps, fascias, fibrous tissue, aponeurosis, galea, and bladder wall. Delicate structures like bowel or vessel walls are avoided due to the risk of tear. So, Allis' forceps can be used to hold fascia and galea aponeurotica in craniotomy, to hold skin flaps & bladder wall and to hold the vaginal wall during hysterectomy.

  • The distal blades are not opposing each other.
  • The tip has got teeth in each blade that are opposing.
  • The proximal part has a ratchet/lock.

  • It has got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestra in each blade
  • Apposing tooth in the tip
  • Lock in the proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold bulky and tough structures, hold lymph nodes.

ii) Babcock’s forceps:

  • Distal part of distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out.
  • Tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations on it.
  • It has got a lock in the proximal part.

Uses:

  • Hold any part of Bowel, Fallopian tube, Appendix, Ureter, Cord, etc.

Apposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades.

Uses:

  • Hold pedicles, tough structures, cut ends of muscles

  • Used for blunt dissection.

  • Used for bile duct stone removal. It may also be used during the removal of kidney, ureteric, or bladder stones.

This is a long and slender instrument. There are finger bows but no catch. The shaft is curved. The blades are small, without serrations, and fenestrated centrally.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with a painless inguinoscrotal swelling. Examination revealed a hard, non-tender swelling in the left hemi-scrotum. It was possible to get above the swelling. The left testis was not palpable separate from the swelling. The ultrasound scan of the left and right testes, labeled as A and B respectively, is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A painless inguinoscrotal swelling and an ultrasound showing a mass that is homogenous, hypoechoic compared to surrounding stroma, and arising from within testes (image A- left testicle) are suggestive of seminoma.

Seminoma is the most common type of Germ cell tumor. The peak incidence is seen in the fourth decade. It usually presents as painless testicular enlargement. Ultrasound is mandatory in all suspected cases of testicular tumors. 

Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface that is devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histology shows sheets of uniform round cells with clear cytoplasm and a large central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus. It is seen as a "fried egg appearance" as shown below.

Placental alkaline phosphate(PLAP) is the tumor marker of seminoma. A rise in hCG is observed in 30% of cases and AFP is never raised in pure seminoma.

Seminoma metastasizes mainly through para-aortic lymph nodes.

An orchidectomy through an inguinal incision is performed as a definitive treatment.

Other options:

Option B-Epididymal cyst occurs due to cystic degeneration of epididymis. They usually occur in middle age and are bilateral. The tense cysts are usually posterior to the testes and feel like clusters of tiny grapes. It is visible on USG as anechoic cysts different from the testes. Treatment involves the excision of the cyst if it is single. Partial or total resection of the epididymis is required in multilocular cysts.

The image below is an ultrasound of the scrotum showing an epididymal cyst.

Option C-Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis in the scrotum. It will be brilliantly transilluminating and testes will be separately palpable. USG will show anechoic (due to fluid) reflection. Treatment involves Jaboulay's operation, in which eversion of sac upon itself is done to prevent refilling of hydrocoele sac.

The image below shows an ultrasound of the scrotum showing an anechoic hydrocele surrounding the testicle.

Option D-Cancer of the scrotum is a rare entity, which previously occurred in chimney sweepers. It presents as a wart or ulcer on the scrotum which may involve testes as it grows. It is treated by excision of the lesion with a margin of normal tissue.

questions.text: A patient underwent a laparotomy for Crohn's disease. A 15 cm segment of the ileum was resected. On the 7th post-operative day, the patient developed an anastomotic leak. He continued to have 150-200 ml fistula output for the next 7 days. There was no collection of fluid in the abdomen. The patient is stable now. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Perform laparotomy and exteriorize the fistula
Conservative management and wait for the fistula to heal

questions.solution:
A 150-200ml of fluid leak from the enterocutaneous (ECF) fistula site can be classified as a low-output fistula. In this case, there is no fluid accumulation in the abdomen, and the patient's condition is stable, hence conservative management is typically provided to this patient, and the fistula is expected to heal.

In the majority of cases, fistulas close spontaneously within the initial 4-week period. Therefore, it is recommended to allow patients a minimum of 8 weeks for spontaneous healing of the fistula before considering surgery. However, surgical intervention becomes necessary in many cases, particularly when unfavorable characteristics are present.

An abnormal connection between the small intestine and the skin can occur due to various factors such as Crohn's disease (CD), radiotherapy, abdominal trauma, or most commonly, as a complication of surgery, either from an anastomotic leak or an unintended enterotomy.

The amount of fluid output from the fistula over a 24-hour period is crucial in determining its physiological impact on the patient's fluid and electrolyte balance and guides the management approach. Enterocutaneous fistulas can be categorized as low-output (less than 200 mL/day), moderate-output (200-500 mL/day), or high-output (greater than 500 mL/day).

Principles of Management of Enterocutaneous Fistula:(SNAP)

  • S - Elimination of Sepsis and skin protection
  • N - Nutrition – A period of parenteral nutrition may well be required
  • A - Anatomical assessment
  • P - Definitive planned surgery
CT scans are the preferred method to identify infected collections, and percutaneous drainage can be performed to address them. It is crucial to protect the skin since small bowel effluent can be corrosive. Nutritional support should include fluid and electrolytes, as they can be lost in significant amounts in cases of proximal fistulas. Additionally, carbohydrates, protein, fat, and vitamins should be included.

Decisions need to be made regarding enteral and parenteral feeding options. Enteral feeding has its advantages, but if the fistula is located proximally or has high output, total parenteral nutrition will be necessary.

Surgery is preferred when conservative management fails or if there is an additional complication. A significant number of patients with enterocutaneous fistulas (ECFs) also require the repair of large abdominal wall defects in addition to fistula surgery. Typically, the fistula is removed by surgical resection, and an end-to-end intestinal anastomosis is performed. Bowel diversion surgery is also done. The introduction of through-the-scope clips has improved the repair of recent injuries when sepsis is under control and the fistula is small in size. However, this technology has limited usefulness in curing long-standing chronic ECF.
