questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the emergency department after suffering a penetrating injury to the neck. On examination, there is a small laceration just above the cricoid cartilage. His vitals were found to be stable. Examination revealed active bleeding from the site of injury. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of penetrating neck injury just above the cricoid cartilage corresponds to zone II neck injury. Although the patient is hemodynamically stable, the presence of hard signs such as active bleeding warrants immediate neck exploration as the next step of management.

Neck trauma is classified based on the different regions of the neck:

  • Zone I: thoracic inlet to cricoid, associated with maximum mortality. It contains large vascular structures as well as the trachea and oesophagus.
  • Zone II: cricoid cartilage to the angle of the mandible, most commonly prone to injury and most easily accessible for surgery. It contains the carotid and vertebral arteries, jugular veins, and structures of the aerodigestive tract.
  • Zone III: angle of the mandible to the base of the skull. Structures within zone III include blood vessels that are difficult to expose surgically.

The following are the indications for immediate surgical exploration of neck trauma. They are also known as the hard signs of neck trauma:

  • Active bleeding 
  • Expanding or pulsatile hematoma
  • Air bubbling from penetrating injury
  • Massive subcutaneous emphysema
  • Hematemesis
  • Presence of neurological deficit
  • Fluid-resistant hemorrhagic shock
  • Audible bruit or palpable thrill
  • Airway compromise

Management:

  •  If the patient is hemodynamically unstable or presence of any hard signs - neck exploration.
  •  If the patient is stable- angiography and angioembolization are indicated. If it fails, then neck exploration should be done.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of hydronephrosis detected during prenatal ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Ureteropelvic junction obstruction is the most common cause of hydronephrosis on prenatal ultrasound among the given options.

The Etiology of Antenatal Hydronephrosis:

Aetiology Incidence
Transient hydronephrosis 41–88%
Ureteropelvic junction obstruction 10–30%
Vesicoureteral reflux 10–20%
Ureterocele/ectopic ureter/duplex system 5–7% 
Posterior urethral valve/urethral atresia 1–2% 

In UPJ obstruction, hydronephrosis may be detected on antenatal ultrasound. It can however be transient or mild and resolves on its own.

The causes of UPJ obstruction are:

  • Intrinsic (due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter) or 
  • Extrinsic (eg. compression by accessory renal arteries). This needs to be corrected primarily.

It is usually associated with renal anomalies and has a 2:1 male-to-female ratio. After birth, re-checking needs to be done and in cases presenting with symptoms of recurrent UTI, palpable flank mass or pain, urinary obstruction, and cases of failure to thrive. If the hydronephrosis is persistent, its severity is graded by the extent of the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system and parenchymal thickness.

In cases of hydronephrosis, long-standing urine stasis and pressure may damage the kidneys. The renal anatomy and function can be assessed using radioscintigraphy studies. MAG3 (mercaptoacetyl triglycine) which measures tubular function has largely replaced the usage of Tc99- DTPA. The kidneys with decreased function show slower uptake and take a longer time to excrete the tracer. It is even preferred over intravenous pyelogram for assessment of hydronephrosis in newborns and children because IVP images are suboptimal in presence of bowel gas and poor dye uptake in newborn kidneys.

Treatment of intrinsic UPJ obstruction is done surgically if renal function is compromised or bilateral kidneys are involved. In other cases, serial follow-up with ultrasonography is done to assess the spontaneous resolution of hydronephrosis.

questions.text: The most widely used approach for evaluating the risk of surgical death in patients undergoing thoracic surgery is the Thoracoscore. Which of the following variables do not comprise the Thoracoscore?
questions.solution:
Society of Thoracic Surgeons (STS) score is not a variable used to calculate mortality risk in patients undergoing thoracic surgery.

The Thoracoscore is the most widely used model to assess the risk of operative mortality in patients undergoing thoracic surgery. The risk is calculated based on nine variables:

  • Age
  • Sex
  • American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) score
  • Performance status
  • Dyspnea score
  • Priority of surgery
  • Extent of surgery
  • Malignant diagnosis
  • Composite comorbidity score

It is currently the best model available to estimate the risk of death when considering patients for thoracic surgery. 

Society of Thoracic Surgeons (STS) score is a risk prediction model that assesses a patient's mortality risk before cardiac surgery. The STS Score is used to screen patients for transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) and to risk stratify patients in major TAVR trials.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is taken up for emergency surgical exploration due to a suspected left sided testicular torsion. On table, the testis is deemed viable. What would be the suitable surgical decision in this case?
questions.solution:
Detorsion of the cord within 6 hours in a case of testicular torsion may salvage testis. If the affected testis is viable after the cord is untwisted, both the affected and the contra-lateral testes are fixed to the scrotum using non-absorbable sutures, as the anatomical predisposition would most likely be bilateral and use of absorbable sutures may lead to recurrence of torsion.

Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord and its contents such that the testicular blood supply becomes compromised. It is a surgical emergency and if left untreated, the testes may become gangrenous. Early surgery undertaken to untwist the testis gives a better outcome .

The following are anatomical predispositions to testicular torsion:

  • High investment of the tunica vaginalis causes the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause in adolescents and is typically a bilateral abnormality
  • Inversion of the testis. The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.
  • Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis. This allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.
 

Males in the age group of 10-25 years present with acute scrotal or groin pain with associated nausea and vomiting. On examination, the scrotum appears swollen and tender. The affected testis may be seen to be positioned higher (Deming's sign) while the contralateral testis may be seen to be position horizontally (Angell's sign).  

A doppler ultrasound may be taken to assess the blood supply but surgical exploration is still indicated as a clinical decision. If the testis is infarcted after the cord is untwisted, an orchidectomy must be undertaken and the opposite testis must be fixed to the scrotum to preserve fertility and prevent torsion. If the affected testis is viable after the cord is untwisted, both the affected and the contra-lateral testes are fixed to the scrotum (bilateral orchiopexy) using non-absorbable sutures.

questions.text: A 57-year-old diabetic patient presented with a painful, malodorous, discoloured scrotum, as shown in the image. The patient was febrile and in extreme pain. Which of the following organisms is not likely to be implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Fournier's gangrene. It is a type of synergistic spreading gangrene. Clostridia botulinum does not cause synergistic spreading gangrene. Clostridium perfringens and Clostridium septicum may be associated with the infection. 

Synergistic spreading gangrene is also called subdermal gangrene or necrotising fasciitis.  A mixed pattern of organisms is responsible: coliforms, staphylococci, bacteroids, anaerobic streptococci, and peptostreptococci have all been implicated, acting in synergy.

Fournier's gangrene is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotising fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as HIV, alcoholism, diabetes, etc. 

SGLT-2 inhibitors like canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin can also cause Fournier's gangrene.

The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of haemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the Dartos, Scarpa's, and Colle's fascia.

Clinical features include pain out of proportion to physical examination findings, fever, prostration, and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus.

The testis is usually not affected. It is a surgical emergency. Diagnosis is majorly clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows:

A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue →, obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin →, gangrene. Thus, a black scrotum with crepitus is seen.

The steps in the management of this condition are:

  1. IV fluids
  2. IV antibiotics
  3. Urgent surgical excision followed by skin grafting in later stages. 

When the infection has been controlled, a vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful. Skin grafting is essential for a patient surviving an acute episode. Abdominal wall infections are known as Meleney's synergistic gangrene.
